phrases.meaning: Things are going well, I have no major problems
phrases.example: How's work going? I can't complain, everything's fine.

phrases.meaning: It sounds simple but is actually difficult to do
phrases.example: Just find a new job? That's easier said than done in this economy.

phrases.meaning: I'm feeling slightly ill or unwell
phrases.example: I'm feeling a bit under the weather today, so I'll work from home.

phrases.meaning: I'll continue to inform you about developments
phrases.example: I'll keep you posted on how the project is progressing.

phrases.english: It's not my cup of tea
phrases.meaning: Something I don't particularly enjoy or like
phrases.example: Horror movies? Not really my cup of tea, to be honest.

phrases.meaning: Let's stop working for today
phrases.example: We've made good progress. Let's call it a day and continue tomorrow.

phrases.meaning: I agree with your argument or opinion
phrases.example: You think we should wait? You've got a point there - rushing might cause problems.

phrases.meaning: I agree with you, we have the same understanding
phrases.example: So you think we need more time too? I'm on the same page.

phrases.meaning: It's better to be cautious than to take risks
phrases.example: Should we bring an umbrella? Better safe than sorry - let's take it.

phrases.english: Don't bite off more than you can chew
phrases.meaning: Don't take on more responsibilities than you can handle
phrases.example: You're already working two jobs and studying? Don't bite off more than you can chew.

phrases.meaning: Something that seems bad but actually has good results
phrases.example: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise - I found a much better one.

phrases.english: You can't have your cake and eat it too
phrases.meaning: You can't have two good things that are mutually exclusive
phrases.example: You want to travel and save money? You can't have your cake and eat it too.

phrases.english: It's no use crying over spilled milk
phrases.meaning: There's no point in worrying about things that have already happened
phrases.example: The mistake is made. It's no use crying over spilled milk - let's focus on fixing it.

phrases.english: Time flies when you're having fun
phrases.meaning: Time passes quickly when you're enjoying yourself
phrases.example: I can't believe it's already midnight! Time flies when you're having fun.

phrases.english: Rome wasn't built in a day
phrases.meaning: Important things take time to accomplish
phrases.example: Learning a language takes time. Rome wasn't built in a day.

phrases.meaning: Very rarely, almost never
phrases.example: I only see my old friends once in a blue moon these days.

phrases.english: By the skin of your teeth
phrases.meaning: Just barely, by a very narrow margin
phrases.example: I passed the exam by the skin of my teeth - I got exactly the minimum score.

phrases.english: Every cloud has a silver lining
phrases.meaning: Every bad situation has some positive aspect
phrases.example: I lost my job, but every cloud has a silver lining - now I can pursue my dream career.

phrases.meaning: Something that seems bad but turns out to be good
phrases.example: Missing the flight was a blessing in disguise - the next one was much cheaper.

phrases.english: To hit the nail on the head
phrases.meaning: To describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem
phrases.example: You hit the nail on the head with your analysis of the problem.

phrases.meaning: Very common, not special or unique
phrases.example: Coffee shops are a dime a dozen in this city.

phrases.meaning: To reveal a secret
phrases.example: I wasn't supposed to tell you, but I spilled the beans about the surprise party.

phrases.meaning: To persuade someone to do something
phrases.example: I didn't want to go, but she twisted my arm and I agreed.

phrases.meaning: To do something in the easiest or cheapest way, often sacrificing quality
phrases.example: They cut corners on the construction, and now the building has problems.

phrases.meaning: To start an activity or process
phrases.example: Let's get the ball rolling on this project next week.

phrases.meaning: To make an extra effort, to do more than is required
phrases.example: She always goes the extra mile to help her customers.

phrases.meaning: To face a difficult situation with courage
phrases.example: I need to bite the bullet and have that difficult conversation with my boss.

phrases.meaning: To work late into the night
phrases.example: I had to burn the midnight oil to finish the report on time.

phrases.meaning: To stop working for the day
phrases.example: We've made good progress. Let's call it a day and continue tomorrow.

phrases.meaning: To become nervous and lose confidence about doing something
phrases.example: I was going to ask for a raise, but I got cold feet at the last moment.

phrases.meaning: I completely agree with you
phrases.example: You think we need more time? I couldn't agree more!

phrases.english: I see where you're coming from
phrases.meaning: I understand your point of view
phrases.example: I see where you're coming from, but I think we should consider other options.

phrases.meaning: A difficult decision to make
phrases.example: Should we expand now or wait? That's a tough call.

phrases.meaning: Very busy with many tasks
phrases.example: Sorry I can't meet today. I'm swamped with work this week.

phrases.meaning: Can you provide more details or explanation?
phrases.example: Could you elaborate on that point about the marketing strategy?

phrases.meaning: I forgot about it
phrases.example: I'm sorry I didn't call you yesterday. It completely slipped my mind.

phrases.meaning: I need time to think about something before deciding
phrases.example: That's an interesting offer. Let me sleep on it and get back to you tomorrow.

phrases.meaning: To avoid talking about something directly
phrases.example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what happened.

phrases.english: The ball is in your court
phrases.meaning: It's your turn to take action or make a decision
phrases.example: I've made my proposal. Now the ball is in your court.

phrases.meaning: I understand and agree with your reasoning
phrases.example: You want to wait until spring to travel? Yeah, that makes sense.

phrases.meaning: I'm undecided, I can't choose between options
phrases.example: I'm on the fence about whether to accept the job offer or not.

phrases.meaning: I can't decide between two options
phrases.example: I'm torn between staying in the city or moving to the countryside.

phrases.meaning: I'm inclined to choose a particular option
phrases.example: I'm leaning towards the blue option, but I'm not completely sure yet.

phrases.meaning: I'm reconsidering my decision, I'm having doubts
phrases.example: I said yes to the job, but now I'm having second thoughts.

phrases.meaning: I'm struggling with something
phrases.example: I'm having a hard time understanding this concept.

phrases.meaning: I don't have much time left
phrases.example: I'm running out of time to finish this project.

phrases.meaning: I'm becoming frustrated, I'm losing my patience
phrases.example: I'm running out of patience with this slow service.

phrases.meaning: I don't have any more creative solutions or suggestions
phrases.example: I'm running out of ideas for the presentation. Can you help?

phrases.meaning: I'm spending more than I have, I'm becoming poor
phrases.example: I'm running out of money this month. I need to be more careful.

phrases.meaning: I don't have many choices left
phrases.example: I'm running out of options for where to live.

phrases.meaning: I'm excited about something that will happen in the future
phrases.example: I'm really looking forward to the vacation next month.

phrases.meaning: I'm investigating or researching something
phrases.example: I'm looking into different options for my career change.

phrases.meaning: I'm trying to find something
phrases.example: I'm looking for a new apartment in the city center.

phrases.meaning: I'm currently doing or developing something
phrases.example: I'm working on a new project that should be finished next week.

phrases.meaning: I'm handling or managing a situation
phrases.example: I'm dealing with a difficult customer at the moment.

phrases.meaning: I'm having difficulty with something
phrases.example: I'm struggling with the new software. It's quite complicated.

phrases.meaning: I'm worried about something
phrases.example: I'm concerned about the deadline. We might not make it.

phrases.meaning: I'm very happy and enthusiastic about something
phrases.example: I'm really excited about the new job opportunity.

phrases.meaning: I'm anxious or concerned about something
phrases.example: I'm worried about the exam next week. I haven't studied enough.

phrases.meaning: I'm sure and certain about something
phrases.example: I'm confident about my ability to complete this project on time.

phrases.meaning: I'm uncertain about something
phrases.example: I'm not sure about the exact date, but I think it's next Friday.

phrases.meaning: I'm completely sure about something
phrases.example: I'm certain about my decision to change careers.

phrases.meaning: I'm committed and determined about something
phrases.example: I'm serious about learning French. I practice every day.

phrases.meaning: I have strong feelings and enthusiasm about something
phrases.example: I'm really passionate about environmental protection.

phrases.meaning: I have doubts about something, I'm not easily convinced
phrases.example: I'm skeptical about the new policy. It might not work as intended.

phrases.meaning: I have positive expectations about something
phrases.example: I'm optimistic about the future of renewable energy.

phrases.meaning: I have negative expectations about something
phrases.example: I'm pessimistic about our chances of winning without our best player.

phrases.meaning: I feel thankful for something
phrases.example: I'm really grateful for all the support you've given me.

phrases.meaning: I'm in charge of or accountable for something
phrases.example: I'm responsible for organizing the team meeting this week.

phrases.meaning: I'm famous or recognized for something
phrases.example: I'm known for being punctual and reliable.

phrases.meaning: I'm well-known for something
phrases.example: This restaurant is famous for its authentic Italian cuisine.

phrases.meaning: I'm prepared for something
phrases.example: I'm ready for the challenge. Let's get started!

phrases.meaning: I'm not prepared for something
phrases.example: I'm not ready for such a big responsibility yet.

phrases.meaning: I'm ready and have made plans for something
phrases.example: I'm prepared for any questions they might ask in the interview.

phrases.meaning: I have the skills or credentials needed for something
phrases.example: I'm qualified for the position. I have all the required experience.

phrases.meaning: I meet the requirements for something
phrases.example: I'm eligible for the scholarship because of my academic performance.

phrases.meaning: I'm appropriate or right for something
phrases.example: I think I'm suitable for this role. I have the right background.

phrases.meaning: I feel thankful to someone
phrases.example: I'm really grateful to my teacher for all her help.

phrases.meaning: I'm dedicated and determined to do something
phrases.example: I'm committed to finishing this project on time.

phrases.meaning: I'm devoted and focused on something
phrases.example: I'm dedicated to improving my language skills.

phrases.meaning: I'm against something, I disagree with it
phrases.example: I'm opposed to the new policy. I think it's unfair.

phrases.meaning: I'm used to something, I'm familiar with it
phrases.example: I'm accustomed to working long hours. It doesn't bother me.

phrases.meaning: I can't stop doing or using something
phrases.example: I'm addicted to coffee. I can't start my day without it.

phrases.meaning: I have a negative physical reaction to something
phrases.example: I'm allergic to peanuts, so I can't eat that.

phrases.meaning: I react strongly to something
phrases.example: I'm sensitive to criticism. It really affects me.

phrases.meaning: I'm not affected by something
phrases.example: I'm immune to his charm. I know what he's really like.

phrases.meaning: I'm near something, either physically or in terms of achievement
phrases.example: I'm close to finishing my degree. Just one more semester!

phrases.meaning: I'm like something or someone
phrases.example: I'm similar to my father in many ways.

phrases.meaning: I'm not the same as something or someone
phrases.example: I'm different from my siblings. We have very different personalities.

phrases.meaning: I know that something is true
phrases.example: I'm aware that this is a difficult situation, but we'll manage.

phrases.meaning: I don't know that something is true
phrases.example: I'm not aware that there were any changes to the schedule.

phrases.meaning: I'm certain that something is true
phrases.example: I'm convinced that this is the right decision for our company.

phrases.meaning: I'm not sure that something is true
phrases.example: I'm not convinced that this approach will work.

phrases.meaning: I'm certain that something is true
phrases.example: I'm sure that we can solve this problem together.

phrases.meaning: I'm uncertain whether something is true
phrases.example: I'm not sure that this is the best solution.

phrases.meaning: I'm completely sure that something is true
phrases.example: I'm certain that I left my keys on the kitchen table.

phrases.meaning: I'm not completely sure that something is true
phrases.example: I'm not certain that this will work, but it's worth trying.

phrases.meaning: I'm sure and certain that something will happen
phrases.example: I'm confident that we'll meet the deadline.

phrases.meaning: I'm not sure that something will happen
phrases.example: I'm not confident that this plan will succeed.

phrases.meaning: I'm optimistic that something will happen
phrases.example: I'm hopeful that we can reach an agreement soon.

phrases.meaning: I'm worried or concerned that something might happen
phrases.example: I'm afraid that we might not have enough time to finish.

phrases.meaning: I'm anxious or concerned that something might happen
phrases.example: I'm worried that we won't be able to complete the project on time.

phrases.meaning: I'm worried about something
phrases.example: I'm concerned that the new policy might have negative effects.

phrases.meaning: I'm very happy that something happened
phrases.example: I'm delighted that you got the job! Congratulations!

phrases.meaning: I'm sad or let down that something happened
phrases.example: I'm disappointed that the concert was cancelled.

phrases.meaning: I didn't expect that something would happen
phrases.example: I'm surprised that you're here already. I thought you'd be late.

phrases.meaning: I'm very surprised and upset that something happened
phrases.example: I'm shocked that they decided to close the factory.

phrases.meaning: I feel better because something good happened or something bad didn't happen
phrases.example: I'm relieved that the test results came back negative.

phrases.meaning: I feel thankful that something happened
phrases.example: I'm grateful that you were able to help me when I needed it.

phrases.meaning: I apologize or feel bad that something happened
phrases.example: I'm sorry that I couldn't make it to your party.
